Solve for 𝑝p:

fraction

STEP: Solve for 𝑝p
[−3 points ⇒ 0 / 3 points left]

To solve a linear equation, we do the same thing to both sides of the equation to get 𝑝p on its own. To do this we must do the opposite of what has been done to 𝑝p.

The 11 has been added to the 𝑝p, so we must subtract 11 from both sides of the equation.

−6𝑝+1−6𝑝+1−1−6𝑝=6=6−1=5−6p+1=6−6p+1−1=6−1−6p=5

Now we can focus on getting the coefficient of 𝑝p to be 11. To get 𝑝p on its own with a coefficient of 11, we must do the opposite of what has been done to 𝑝p. We must divide both sides of the equation by −6−6.

−6𝑝−6𝑝−6𝑝𝑝=5=5−6=5−6=−56−6p=5−6p−6=5−6p=5−6p=−56
NOTE: You might have tried to solve this equation by first dividing both sides by the coefficient of 𝑝p (which is −6−6 in this case). This would give you the correct answer, as long as you remembered to divide 11 by −6−6. But, this method can create fractions that are difficult to work with. (It is also easy to forget to divide 11 by −6−6!) It is best to first deal with the number, and only divide by the coefficient of 𝑝p as the very last step.
